Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: IPY: Arctic System Reanalysis
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will develop an Arctic System Reanalysis (ASR). The ASR, which can be viewed as a blend of modeling and observations, will provide a high resolution description in space (20 km) and time (3 h) of the atmosphere-sea ice-land surface system of the Arctic. The ASR will ingest historical data streams along with measurements of the physical components of the Arctic Observing Network being developed as part of the IPY. Gridded fields from the ASR, such as temperature, radiation and winds, will also serve as drivers for coupled ice-ocean, land surface and other models, and will offer a focal point for coordinated model inter-comparison efforts. The ASR will permit reconstructions of the Arctic system's state, thereby serving as a state-of-the-art synthesis tool for assessing Arctic climate variability and monitoring Arctic change. The ASR will also shape the legacy observing network of the IPY by providing a vehicle for observing system sensitivity studies. The first generation ASR as outlined here will span the years 2000-2010.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Arctic System Reanalysis (ASR) has produced a very detailed description of the behavior of the Arctic atmosphere, Arctic Ocean sea ice cover, and Arctic land areas from 2000 until 2012. The area covered by ASR (see figure) extends from the middle latitudes (roughly 40°N latitude) to the North Pole, completely encompassing the rivers that flow northward to the Arctic Ocean and help to preserve its sea ice cover.  In addition, ASR extends from the Earth’s surface to the edge of space. ASR merged a vast array of observations from the surface, atmosphere, and from satellites into gridded analyses of numerous atmospheric, land, and sea ice variables. Data are provided every 15 and 30 kilometers at three hour intervals.  During the ASR period, the region has experienced rapid climate change for reasons that are not well understood. ASR is being used to investigate a wide variety of climate and climate change phenomena affecting the greater Arctic, such as storms and terrain modified surface winds. The much higher spatial resolution than global reanalyses along with the Arctic optimized observational merging is revealing many new aspects the Arctic environment and how and why it is responding to climate change. The ASR data are freely available to the world wide scientific community through the National Center for Atmospheric Research’s Data Support Section.

Figure caption:   Area (or domain) covered by the Arctic System Reanalysis is inside the purple square. The outer domain is used to provide smooth information at the edges of the inner domain.
